<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 305, 304, 320]]<|/det|>
## FURTHER MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 328, 154, 344]]<|/det|>
Paper 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[784, 305, 907, 320]]<|/det|>
9231/12  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[784, 328, 907, 344]]<|/det|>
May/June 2017  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 350, 907, 365]]<|/det|>
3 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 370, 418, 386]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 392, 468, 408]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: List of Formulae (MF10)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 418, 390, 435]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 448, 787, 464]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of this page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 464, 327, 479]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 479, 504, 495]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 495, 504, 510]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 510, 380, 525]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 540, 285, 555]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 555, 910, 586]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 586, 507, 600]]<|/det|>
The use of a calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 600, 910, 630]]<|/det|>
Results obtained solely from a graphic calculator, without supporting working or reasoning, will not receive credit.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 630, 608, 646]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 659, 606, 674]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 674, 757, 690]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 915, 92]]<|/det|>
Prove, by mathematical induction, that \(5^{n} + 3\) is divisible by 4 for all non-negative integers \(n\). [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[921, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 73, 156, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 601, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(k\) for which the set of linear equations

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 100, 567, 118]]<|/det|>
\[x + 3y + kz = 4,\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 119, 578, 137]]<|/det|>
\[4x - 2y - 10z = -5,\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[425, 139, 566, 157]]<|/det|>
\[x + y + 2z = 1,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 163, 346, 180]]<|/det|>
has no unique solution.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 163, 920, 180]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 156, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 824, 92]]<|/det|>
For this value of \(k\), find the set of possible solutions, giving your answer in the form

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 98, 556, 144]]<|/det|>
\[\begin{pmatrix} x \\ y \\ z \end{pmatrix} = \mathbf{a} + t\mathbf{b},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 152, 499, 170]]<|/det|>
where \(\mathbf{a}\) and \(\mathbf{b}\) are vectors and \(t\) is a scalar.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 152, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 307, 92]]<|/det|>
The matrix \(\mathbf{A}\), given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 92, 579, 144]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{A} = \left( \begin{array}{ccc}1 & 2 & -2\\ 6 & 4 & -6\\ 6 & 5 & -7 \end{array} \right),\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 148, 358, 166]]<|/det|>
has eigenvalues 1, \(-1\) and \(-2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 180, 156, 198]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 180, 487, 198]]<|/det|>
Find a set of corresponding eigenvectors.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 180, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 73, 156, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 667, 92]]<|/det|>
Calculate the exact value of \(I_{1}\) and deduce the exact value of \(I_{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 78, 94, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 75, 153, 96]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
Let \(z = \cos \theta + \mathrm{i}\sin \theta\). Show that \(z - \frac{1}{z} = 2\mathrm{i}\sin \theta\) and hence express \(16\sin^{5}\theta\) in the form \(\sin 5\theta +p\sin 3\theta +q\sin \theta\), where \(p\) and \(q\) are integers to be determined.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 100, 920, 119]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 79, 154, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 72, 526, 112]]<|/det|>
Hence find the exact value of \(\int_{0}^{\frac{1}{3}\pi} 16 \sin^5 \theta \, \mathrm{d}\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 79, 920, 98]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 153, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 593, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the general solution of \((*)\), giving \(y\) in terms of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 104, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 73, 863, 92]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has polar equation \(r = a(1 + \sin \theta)\) for \(-\pi < \theta \leqslant \pi\), where \(a\) is a positive constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 104, 156, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 104, 240, 122]]<|/det|>
Sketch \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 390, 154, 409]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 390, 495, 409]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the region enclosed by \(C\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 390, 920, 409]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 85, 153, 103]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 78, 920, 129]]<|/det|>
Show that the substitution \(u = 1 + \sin \theta\) reduces this integral for \(s\) to \((\sqrt{2})a \int_{0}^{2} \frac{1}{\sqrt{(2 - u)}} \mathrm{d}u\). Hence evaluate \(s\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 112, 920, 131]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 104, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 73, 524, 92]]<|/det|>
Answer only **one** of the following two alternatives.

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 201, 122]]<|/det|>
# EITHER

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 561, 154]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) has equation \(y = \frac{1}{2} (\mathrm{e}^{x} + \mathrm{e}^{-x})\) for \(0\leqslant x\leqslant 4.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 168, 156, 185]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 166, 920, 201]]<|/det|>
The region \(R\) is bounded by \(C\), the \(x\)-axis, the \(y\)-axis and the line \(x = 4\). Find, in terms of e, the coordinates of the centroid of the region \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 183, 920, 201]]<|/det|>
<mark>[10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 77, 153, 95]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\frac{\mathrm{d}s}{\mathrm{d}x} = \frac{1}{2} (\mathrm{e}^{x} + \mathrm{e}^{-x})\), where \(s\) denotes the arc length of \(C\), and find the surface area generated when \(C\) is rotated through \(2\pi\) radians about the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 100, 920, 118]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 153, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>OR</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 507, 123]]<|/det|>
The position vectors of the points \(A, B, C, D\) are

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[290, 131, 707, 149]]<|/det|>
\[\mathbf{i} + \mathbf{j} + 3\mathbf{k},\quad 3\mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} + 5\mathbf{k},\quad 3\mathbf{i} - \mathbf{j} + \mathbf{k},\quad 5\mathbf{i} - 5\mathbf{j} + \alpha \mathbf{k},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 156, 920, 191]]<|/det|>
respectively, where \(\alpha\) is a positive integer. It is given that the shortest distance between the line \(AB\) and the line \(CD\) is equal to \(2\sqrt{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 203, 156, 221]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 203, 529, 221]]<|/det|>
Show that the possible values of \(\alpha\) are 3 and 5.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 203, 920, 221]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 74, 153, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Using \(\alpha = 3\), find the acute angle between the planes \(ABC\) and \(ABD\), giving your answer in degrees.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 88, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 840, 920, 875]]<|/det|>
